qas.question: What is the translation of text that is sung closely linked to?
What is most vocal music set to in Western tradition?
What type of forms does popular music tend to retain?
What type of example an be found of translating poetry for singing?
Who translated German chorales into English?
What is the translation of text that is sung never linked to?
What is all vocal music set to in Western tradition?
What forms does popular music tend to refrain from?
What type of example can not be found of translating poetry for singing?
Who translated Chinese chorales into English?

context: Translation of a text that is sung in vocal music for the purpose of singing in another language—sometimes called "singing translation"—is closely linked to translation of <a0_0>poetry<a0_0/> because most vocal music, at least in the Western tradition, is set to <a1_0>verse<a1_0/>, especially <b6_0>verse<b6_0/> in regular patterns with rhyme. (Since the late 19th century, musical setting of prose and free verse has also been practiced in some art music, though popular music tends to remain conservative in its retention of <a2_0><b7_0>stanzaic<b7_0/><a2_0/> forms with or without refrains.) A rudimentary example of translating <b5_0>poetry<b5_0/> for singing is <a3_0><b8_0>church hymns<b8_0/><a3_0/>, such as the German chorales translated into English by <a4_0><b9_0>Catherine Winkworth<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
